sentence: San Francisco-based Salesforce.com ( CRM ) has shown consistently strong earnings and revenue growth in recent years.
[ibd-display-video id=2368044 width=50 float=left autostart=true] In fiscal 2015-17, the company grew earnings 49%, 44% and 35%.
Revenue growth was 32%, 24% and 26% in the same years.
Because the fiscal year ends in January, the market expects to get the final numbers for the year in February.
Analysts see earnings rising 33% on a 24% pop in revenue.
While there has been some erosion in annual growth, the changes are too small to worry about.
Margins are another thing to watch when fiscal 2018 results are released.
Pretax margins stepped up from 8.3% to 10%, 11.8% and 12.9% in recent years.
Salesforce.com's stock sketched and broke out of three bases in 2017.
Gains from the ideal buy point to the start of the next consolidation were 9% after an April breakout, then 7% and 11% from the breakouts in August and October.
The current consolidation began forming in November.
The potential buy point is 109.29 with the 5% buy zone stretching to 114.75.
Salesforce shares are trying to poke above that entry now.
Because the earlier bases advanced less than 20% after each breakout, the base count technically remains first stage.
But an investor might expect the next breakout to behave more like a second-stage base than a first-stage base - primarily because the stock has already enjoyed a long run from its low in 2008.
What does this mean to investors?
Investors should lower their expectations.
If the stock breaks out in strong volume and an investor buys shares, then the investor should set the profit-taking level at 20%, or 131.14.
The 20% gain is measured from the ideal buy point, not the place the investor buys.
So the investor who buys at the top of the 5% buy zone (114.75), for example, would sell at 131.14 for a 14% profit.
Some investors often buy stocks high in the 5% buy zone and then complain that they rarely see a 20% gain.
This will happen if they are measuring from their entry rather than the proper ideal entry.
Publishing software provider Adobe Systems ( ADBE ) ends its fiscal year in November.
In 2015-17, earnings rose 56%, 45% and 43%.
Revenue increased 16%, 22% and 25% in the same years.
The Street expects earnings to grow 29% in fiscal 2018 on a revenue gain of 19%.
Pretax margin in 2017 was 37.5%, the highest in at least nine years.
Adobe broke out of bases in January and October in 2017.
The January breakout led to a 42% gain in about eight months.
The October breakout brought a 12% gain in about five weeks.
The buy point is 186.37.
Adobe inched above the buy point recently, but volume was below average and declining.
Watch to see if big volume can kick in and thereby validate the breakout.
